head.title: Oil-Tank Cleanups Caught In the Web of Bureaucracy

hedline.hl1: Oil-Tank Cleanups Caught In the Web of Bureaucracy

abstract.p: Bruce M Resch letter on July 9 article about leaking residential oil tanks blames insurance companies and bureaucratic red tape for clean-up delays (S)

Re: ''The Beast Lurking Under the Lawn'' [July 9], about leaking residential oil tanks.
We indeed do have a serious problem on Long Island and it is most important that the problem be fixed before it becomes a catastrophe.

The beast, however, lurks not only beneath us but rather all around us: Red tape and insurance-company bottom lines contribute greatly to this problem. All sides must work together, with the costs of cleanups borne by those most at fault or by their insurance companies.
That should be a simple issue, but the waters are always muddied when money is involved.
Also lurking in the background of this black comedy are state officials who felt it their duty to send bills for the cleanup to the only innocent party in the article.
This sends a clear message that we should not point out environmental disasters, unless we are prepared to pay to fix them.
Finally we come to the Department of Environmental Conservation, whose regional director, Ray E. Cowen, is satisfied with this cleanup as it stands.
When confronted with evidence of ongoing oil infiltration into the soil, he states that the homeowner has complied with guidelines ''to the extent practicable.''
Would Mr. Cowen care to drink some of the oil-laced water? Would his insurance company cover his hospitalization if he did?
